title: PrintrBoard Enclosure for PrintrBot Simple Metal

description.text: I got tired of reaching under the build plate to connect power and USB and the SD card. You will need to add some length to the power connector.

comments.text: I have made 5 attempts to print the Triple gear with an FDM 3D printer (Flux3D Delta).  All have failed.  I get about 1/3 of the way printed, and then the PLA ends up a mess, due I think to stringing and then scraping of the toolhead on the already-printed surface.  I have tried with and without support, and both the hollow and solid versions of the Triple gear.  I'd appreciate any suggestions.  Toolhead temperature?  Layer height?  Retract toolhead?
comments.author: debrota

comments.text:
what software did you use to slice? I would try various slicers.
In my experience a part like this should be printable at 20% infill , I wouldnt do 100 % you will get the strings and such. I would also try and run the lowest temperature possible to reduce stringing. Also when I have the toolhead scraping problem I change the layer size to something thicker so ie... .25 to .30 , that usually helps. Either way you need to reduce the amount of filament extruded by a fraction of what it is now. You can also do this with diameter size and nozzle size ie tricking it into extruding less filament.

If you have ever used an air pump to get air into your fish tank, you will know that these things vibrate and are really noisy....  
This frame allow the pump to be suspended from the top of a aquarium cabinet on a rubber band which dampens the movement and make the pump almost silent.  
No more folding up cloths and bits of foam under the pump to silence it.

Print out the file (fits in a 160mm square bed space) and screw together with 3mm screws, self tappers work best.  
Attach rubber band to cabinet top and then to the frame, stick the pump on the frame and thats it.  
Printed in ABS, at 15% infill, took about 45 minutes.

remixed_from.author: thruit00
remixed_from.title: PLA Replicator Ducted Fan Clips Modded

title: FlashForge Creator Pro - reversed fan duct

description.text:
I tried to print one of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:191297, but it requires a longer screw which I just don't have.
The longest screw sold by nearby hardware store is 35mm, which is the same length as the ones that came with the machine, and they were just too short, I need the extra 5mm... So I just designed my own! This duct serves as the spacer, the fan housing, and the fan duct.
I install the duct with the original 35mm screw, then install the fan, and yeah no extra 5mm needed. You can still mount the fan to the cartridge, but this way:
  • you will need 2 very long screw per extruder, that is, 11mm for fan, 12mm for spacer, 1.5mm for heat sink, 15mm for the aluminum mounting block, plus 5mm into the stepper motor, that's 44.5mm, so you might want to get some 45mm M3 screw...
  • you lose the ability to quickly switch between PLA mode and ABS mode.
    • I designed a cover to change wind direction, so it's a easy switch between PLA and ABS (or any material you want it to cool down faster or slower)
  • when printing PLA (or other materials that requires faster cooling), you cover the upper air path and have the fan reversed (sucking air from the heat sink), so the wind blows around the just extruded material.
  • when printing ABS (or other materials that requires slower cooling), you cover the bottom air path, leave the upper path open, and have the fan forward (blowing air into the heat sink), so no air blowing the just extruded material.

This is designed for my printer (FlashForge Creator Pro), but it should mount on any similar extruders. I've heart that some printers have the aluminum mounting blocks mounted on different position, so you might need longer/shorter duct.
For me, that's around 34mm from the edge of the aluminum block to the edge of the edge of the cartridge, so this duct leaves around 35mm space over there.
If your printer has a different length, just don't print this, you will either
  • not be able to mount it, because it's too short
  • hit the front door when the cartridge goes to Ymax, because it's too long.
    • I printed this with PLA, but it might be better to print in ABS, because the built-in spacer is touching the heatsink and the screws, and those would get to around 50C~60C during print (depends on environment temperature), and PLA do gets soft in that temperature.
    If you printed this in PLA, DO NOT turn on the "disable fan for the first X layers / height" options in your slicer software, or you either get deformation, or the spacer melts and the screws sunken into the spacer. sorry, but this thing DO need support to print. My print options:
  • PLA @ 220c nozzle / 60c bed (to get a good adherence)
  • 60mm/s perimiter & infill, 50% speed for external permiter & solid infills, 30mm/s for bridge & overhangs.
  • 0.2mm layer height
  • supports
    • After print, you might want to remove the supports and overhangs around the fan housing very well, or you will have problem slide the fan in/out... (that happened to me... I squeeze the fan in and have a hard time digging it out...)

description.text: I recently converted a Mossberg 500A shotgun into a bullpup configuration using an aftermarket stock kit. The slide grip texture and ergonomics left a lot to be desired so I decided to design an adapter that would allow a Houge rubberized overmold forend grip to be mounted to the slide. I was going to design end-caps that would be secured to the core via bolts that would thread into inserts in the core. I have yet to design the end-caps and probably won't since this concept was ultimately abandoned in favor of an aggressively textured polymer one piece design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:789051. However, this concept might be useful in attaching a Houge grip in a more generic manner, such as to a picatinny rail perhaps (note: current design has recessed bolt holes that will only allow mounting to the specific bullpup stock kit slide used). If anyone would like to remix in that direction please let me know via comment and I will gladly provide the CAD file.

author: Warbird

description.text:
This is a motor mount for profile foamy RC airplanes.  The default size is for 2204/14 brushless outrunner motor with an X-mount mounted on 6mm foam.  It's configurable for different motor sizes and foam thicknesses. (You will need to use #2 servo screws or 2mm bolts.)  I've included the .scad file so you can change parameters to create one for your motor and plane.  
Enjoy!

To install the mount after printing, put glue on the flat peg surfaces and on the part of the flat plate that will contact the front "cross" of the airplane.  Use #2 servo screws to attach the motor's mount to the plastic mount.  
To customize the mount to match the dimensions of your motor and foam, open the .scad file with OpenSCAD (or other suitable program), and edit the 4 parameters near the top of the file.   Then re-render and export to STL.  (Example: If you want to use 2mm bolts and nuts instead of screws, you can shorten the pegs by setting a smaller screwlength - see instructions in .scad file.  The second .stl file shows an example of this with a thicker front plate and for 3mm foam.)  
Use of the parameters is documented in the .scad file, but if you have questions, please post them in the comments below and I will try to answer.  
[NOTE:  The screw/bolt diameter is NOT parameterized.  If your motor requires larger screw/bolt size, you will need to dig a bit deeper into the code and do a remix. Hopefully the comments will help a little bit - but you will need to know some SCAD.]

author: protodeals

title: Raspberry Pi holder/mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a holder (mount) that fits on a Prusa i3 frame (could probably work on other printers as well, with some adaptions), and it was designed to hold a Raspberry with a case, unlike many other holders found here. I prefer to have my RPi in a standard case, and just slide it into the holder when I use it with Octoprint on my Prusa i3 printer.  
The STL file contains a holder for a Raspberry Pi model B case, with a dimension of 72x28.5 mm, which fits a Prusa i3 alu frame with a width of 55 mm and a thickness of 6 mm. You can also download the OpenSCAD file, which is a full generator for any size of case and almost any type of Prusa i3 frame, you can set the measurements by changing some variables (see instructions for more info).

The included STL file will print a holder that fits a Raspberry Pi model B case with a width of 72 mm and a height of 28.5 mm, and it fits a Prusa i3 alu frame with 6 mm thickness. I recommend to print it using ABS, as it needs to flex a bit when you snap it to the frame. If you print using PLA, be careful when mounting it. There are two holes for screws, but in my case the friction is enough to keep it in place.  
If you need a holder for other dimensions of Pi cases, like for the B+ or the new version 2, you can download the OpenSCAD file and simply change the variables in the beginning of the file, and generate a new STL file. It should work for most combination of case and frame, I hope.

description.text:
I thought I'd give it a shot at removing the windows and allowing openings through the form. 
So far i've only had time to remove some of the external windows and most of the internal space. And so far it prints rather nicely. 
If you have ooze dialed in then this will print quite well. 
With time i'll open up all of the openings and see how it goes with printing. As it is i'd anticipate pretty well but time will tell I suppose.

If you can angle your fill layers to 45 degrees then there will be less overhang troubles in the top of the main void spaces of the building. I'm sure i've seen this option but can't recall where off the top of my head. 
Regardless it prints well enough and is tricky to fault given its size.

author: HenryRSeymour

description.text:
A simple, reinforced, no zip-tie version of Prusa i3 x-carriage.
Features a TAZ inspired belt holder (simple yet it works perfectly). Update V3:
1). No longer uses any screws to hold the x-carriage. Update V2:
1). Reversed recessed hole that holds the nut (allows you to tighten facing down).
2). Added thickened support and L shaped belt holder to further improve the design.
3). Added side supports to ensure the plastic can't snap under tension. Now holds the belt even tighter with less screw tension! Source SketchUp file included. I designed this x-carriage mount for use with Greg's Wade V5 for Prusa i3 however it will work for any extruder that mounts using 24mm holes (which is basically all of them). author: ceepersdee

title: Canon FD lens adapter for GuerillaBeam

description.text: For adapting Canon FD lenses to GuerillaBeam projectors (with the ability to focus to infinity). Unlike the other GuerillaBeam lens adapters lens adapters, this one is not very robust. (that's why it's separate). If you'd like to connect an FD lens to GuerillaBeam, I'd rather recommend an adapter to an intermediary lens mount. Focus to infinity can still be achieved this way, by attaching to the shorter light side of GuerillaBeam and using an extension tube.

• Print in the highest quality possible.
  • Using thick shells instead of infill will increase stability.
  • For best results slice with Cura
  • You can use an edding 780 gloss paint marker for the lens mounting index

remixed_from.author: kresty
remixed_from.title: Miele G2143SC Dishwasher Top Rack Wheel Stop Clip 2154400 Replacement

title: Blocks to reinforce the plastic bits on my microwave door.  Seriously?

description.text:
MICROWAVES ARE DANGEROUS.  DON'T MESS WITH THIS!  
For want of 10 cents of plastic, my Kenmore Microwave door latch holder fell apart.  
So when I superglue'd it back together I decided to add some reinforcing blocks to the clips.  
Kenmore Microwave 4018008370 - Part is like $120++ from Sears, but I diagnosed the problem, printed the bricks and put it back together in like 2 hours, including uploading this Thing!  
Microwaves can be dangerous, and you definitely don't want the door latch to say it's latched when it isn't.  Please don't do anything stupid with this.  
I figured I'd try this since the Dishwasher Clips I printed 4 1/2 months ago seem to be still going strong.  Hopefully this'll last more than 3 days.

No.  Microwaves are dangerous.  
Photos show before & after with the broken bits, and then the broken bits glued in with reinforcement.  Also extra reinforcement where clips were getting loose.

comments.text: I'll assume you only reenforced it, and the status of the switches wasn't affected. That should be fine.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Interesting. Yea, it's exactly how it was and doesn't impact the switches at all. I just posted it because
A) Why do they build such "cheap" things? It's a "good" microwave, but has silly mechanical failure points to save 10 cents of plastic. So we throw it out and buy a new one or something, wasting resources and energy.
B) I thought it was really strange that I "fixed" it with my printer. Granted I didn't need to reinforce them, but I was afraid that just superglueing it back together would fail.
It fits great now...
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: It's still working... Haven't given it much thought - for a while I was wondering if it was going to break again or not close or something.  Just looking at my old things and saw this :)
comments.author: kresty

description.text: This is a pillow block for an open 12mm (ID) linear bearing you'll find it is split in half. This is for ease of printing with no support material. I've found it to be a wonderfully cheap and functional alternative to spending $40+ on a steel or aluminum pillow block bearing this size. On the next print, I'll probably scale up a hair because I had to sand down the interior a little.

description.text:
Please consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/DanielNoree This is a first go at a OpenRC Quadcopter. starting was to create a different design than what we usually see for 3D printed quads and enclose all electronics in the design itself. The idea was an experiment to create parts from a strong material with thin walls and low infill to keep the weight down. Everything is designed to fit the electronics from a DJI 450 Flamewheel. As you may have noticed i call this a "Beta" version and that is because it´s simply not finished. While all parts do fit together there are things missing in the design. Hopefully someone can get something out of this project, maybe use parts of the design or it can spark ideas for new projects. Video: https://youtu.be/mrUXqSQkN7I The battery compartment extender by Stefan Ekstam can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1211687 Like my FaceBook page - https://www.facebook.com/Daniel-Nor%C3%A9e-576194949211855/
Subscribe to my YouTube channel - https://www.youtube.com/user/DanielNoree2 INSTAGRAM https://www.instagram.com/danielnoree/

This thing is a stand to test the performance of different combinations of motors, propellers and batteries used in model aircraft like quadcopters. The stand is intended to be used with a digital scale to measure the thrust produced by the motor. Thrust is measured as the motor forces the probe of the stand down on to the digital scale. Necessary Hardware Sourced from McMaster Carr:
Standoff: Catalog #93330A450 (x1)
Screws: Catalog #91735A104 (x2) Recommended Digital Scale Sourced from Amazon
Scale: ASIN #B003MSZBSI The test stand is laser cut from 3mm acrylic and assembled with a solvent. Source files including the vector templates used by Ponoko for laser cutting services are included.

This thing was designed to minimize the distance between cup and coffee outlet of the machine. Update:
v2 was optimized for printing without support an turned around 180°

The BMW Z4 (E85) doesn't have a flat surface in its cabin to mount a traditional phone holder, the cup holders fold into the dash and and the  vents are flimsy. It is a pain to fit phones or sat navs to! I have tried many many different mounts and decided to have a go at making one instead.  
I didn't want to drill, glue or damage the dash, but as my car gets used on track a fair bit, I wanted a good firm mount.  
The fit between the instrument cluster and dash trim is a deep slot, plenty strong enough to give a firm grip on the holder. With a little push and a bit of rubber (old inner tube), the holder is held in really firmly.  
Not had chance to test it cornering on track, but its working fine on road....

Printed at 15% infill.
ABS 250C extruder, 90C bed.
Supports
3 walls
Skirt
2 hours 20min

description.text: A simple side hook filament guide for the M3D micro printer. If you are using the M3D initial spool (from the M3D download section), this will reduce the drag of the filament over the side of the chassis and the spool holder hook. The opening for the filament in the guide is designed a small bit larger than the 1.75mm filament to allow for easy flow to the extruder. Depending on the resolution of your printer, you may want to use a round needle file to smooth it out. I did on my print and it works beautifully. UPDATE: I have uploaded a V1.1 version of model. In this version I have engaged the guide opening a small amount to try to save people from having to use a file to smooth it out. UPDATE: I created an angled version as well to see which works better. Check out my version 2.0. UPDATE: I created another angled version that allows the filament to enter the guide from multiple angles. Check out my version 3.0.

I took some measurements with some digital calipers and a few tries later had the general shape for the M3D chassis hook. Since I didn't like the way the filament was riding along the side of the chassis with the default spool holder, I made this. I hope you like it.

title: Replicator/FlashForge Heatsink Spacer (works on other Replicator clones)

description.text:
Simple spacer made off originals in case lost for senior design project.  It measures 3.3mm ID, 7mm OD, 9mm tall.  
This is the spacer that goes in between the heatsink and the fan on MakerBot Replicator/clones for those not familiar with that type of printer.  
I lost a few so I needed to print moar.  Printing in ABS is recommended in case they melt (haven't actually tried PLA).

Measured and made in seconds, render took about 5 mins of screwing around, not going for any beauty contests here. Recommended print settings:
100%
1 shell
.2mm layer height (doesn't really matter)

Adjustable tension GT2 belt connector for RigidBot printers, designed to be used with Alex Lee's idler pulley upgrade. Uses a 30-35mm M3 screw (longer if you want a wider tension adjustment range) and a M3 lock nut. I'd recommend printing this in ABS or other plastics with higher glass transition temperatures (PLA may fail if used near the heated bed). The 1mm gap version has looser tolerances between the connector and the insert. The x and y axis parts are the same, just mirrored. Printer: RigidBot Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)
-- IC3D Black ABS

comments.text: The normal (non 1mm gap) pieces fit together perfectly. I'm amazed at how well the belt fits in, it's much easier to insert the belt than in the stock clip. I did have a problem in that the two mounting holes don't go through. :( It's probably a bit different on my printer due to the e3d v6 hotend. I just drilled them out with a 2.5mm drill bit and it seems to hold... If it comes loose I'll probably just put a 3mm ID brass threaded insert in with a soldering iron.

title: Ring of Gyges from the short story "Ripper's Ring"

description.text: I'm new to this but I had a close friend design and print the Ring of Gyges (the invisibility ring from Plato's Republic); the ring also featured in my story "Ripper's Ring" which will launch at http://www.gypsyshadow.com/StevenSouthard.html#top on May 1, 2015. The triangular 'stone' rotates. When the stone's pointed toward the base of the hand, you disappear, and you reappear when you rotate the stone toward your fingertips. Haven't been able to make myself actually vanish yet, but I'll keep trying.

This is a backlighting box for the Custom QR Code generator.  
It uses 9 x 3mm white LEDs.  
Used it at SoliDoodle's 3D Printing Expo after-party.  While it worked great in my lab, using my Android phone, with the AT&T supplied code scanner, I found out at the party that Apple's Code Scanner didn't read it.   However, when I saw people scanning the code - unsuccessfully - I would just approach them and introduce myself and my product line...   Better than a website link, many people remarked...

run the QR code customizer with the following options: QR Code Data Display Method = 1
QR Code Mirroring = NO
Select Main Object = 4
Thickness option = 1.8
round_corner = 1
rounded corner_num = 0
Width of object = 80
Height of object = 80
Thickness of object = 5
Distance from tag edge. = 0
Wall thickness of perimeter = 8
Wall height of perimeter = 02
Scale multiplier for code = 2.5
QR tolerance = 0.001
X location of QR code center = 0
Y location of QR code center = 0
Z location of bottom of QR code geometry = 1
Thickness of QR code = 2;
Rotate QR code around z-axis = 0
Input from data generator for dimension of QR code (copy and paste from QR SIZE.txt) = 33 When printing the QR CODE, once all the flat base layers have been printed in white and the actual code layers start getting printed, switch up your filament to black. This will provide the contrasting color needed for the QR Code to work. THIS IS CRITICAL ! Print all the other parts. (all black except the INNER LED BOX - which should be white)
clean up the holes for the 3mm LEDs
The back of the inner LED BOX prints on the bottom. the front of the box (the "sleeve") faces up during printing. The LEDS poke through the back towards the front... power up those fine LEDs. I used a 9 VDC power supply, wiring up 3 parallel rows, and then putting those 3 rows in series, with a 100 ohm resistor on the + side of the incoming power line. -- NOTE -- you should check out one of the many LED schematic calculators available on-line to make sure you're LEDs will function properly, without burning them out. insert the QR code into the outer box, code facing the rim of the outer boxhole in the
insert the inner LED BOX sleeve first, and slide it all the way forward.
run the power supply line through the hole in the rear cover. you can glue it all together, but it's a tight fit, so it probably won't be needed. once complete, this box can be attached to anything - making a cool and VERY OBVIOUS QR Code for people to scan. I will be updating this soon, as I do want to make this work properly.
Anyone who does build one of these, please report back with your QR Generator Settings, if you get the resulting QR Code to work reliably...

description.text: Continuing with my OpenSCAD spree, I parameterized the hot glue stick dispenser I did earlier. Now you can make a dispenser for any cylindrical object, such as the AAA batteries shown. It should also work for small "nugget" type objects like nuts, as long as you turn off the front openings (by setting them to zero). The AAA battery holder shown is a little small, since I only wanted to test the script, but it should be able to produce storage of any arbitrary size and strength.

Make sure that your slicer adds supports -- Cura didn't when my walls were too thin.  I ended up fixing it by setting the wall thickness to 0.399 instead of 0.40, so there was an "interior" to support.

This is the display model to a modular planetary gear system, which has only one planetary gear for each sun gear. Being that this system is modular - each module consisting of a planet holder planetary, sun, and annular gear - it can be built upon as much as one wants. Each unit has a input-output ratio of 15/68 or 4.533 turns of the crank to every turn in output. This means that by connecting a mere 10 together, the combined ratio is 1:3,665,866 or 3,665,866 turns of the crank to one turn in output. The components can be found under "Single Planetary Gear System (Components)" or thing:793604.

This bearing holder for LM8UU bearing is designed to lay flat on y-carriage with an additional zero vertical height. It consists of 2 brackets that enclose the bearing from the sides. The precision depends upon the parallel line up of the mounting holes in the y-carriage.   
I recently ordered a prusa I3 derivative aluminium frame from a 3D printer shop in Spain. The machine drilled y-carriage is specified to have drilled holes for SC10UU bearings. In order to use my LM8UU bearings, I designed this kind of holder. The measures of the mounting holes are dx=28mm and dy=21mm. Use 4x M5 20mm bolts to mount the bearing holder.  
Feel free to adjust the spacing in the OpenSCAD-file.
You can use sand paper to get a flat bottom of the holder. It increases the tension on the bearing, too.

title: Angled motor mounts for Diatone FPV250 quad copter

description.text: Motor mounts with bolt hole pattern for the Daitone FPV250 airframe.  Angles the motors down 10 degrees for less drag when racing.

.15mm layers, 15% infill.
Thick pieces fit between the motor and the frame, F side to frame.
Thin pieces go on the underside of the frame, f side to frame, to align the bolts with the upper wedge.

I scale it up to about 3cm in diameter and print with white PLA.
For more information about the Ingress Engineer Badge look here: http://decodeingress.me/ingress-manual/badges/engineer-badge/
I usually scale this to 3 cm across.
This is a model of the Ingress Illuminator Badge. You can learn more about it here: http://decodeingress.me/ingress-manual/badges/illuminator-badge/
I usually print the badge at 3 cm across. Then I hand paint to make it beautiful.

These are the components for a modular planetary gear system, which has only one planetary gear for each sun gear. Being that this system is modular - each module consisting of a planet holder, planetary, sun, and annular gear - it can be built upon as much as one wants. Each unit has a input-output ratio of 15/68 or 4.533 turns of the crank to every turn in output. This means that by connecting a mere 10 together, the combined ratio is 1:3,665,866 or 3,665,866 turns of the crank to one turn in output. The display model can be found under "Single Planetary Gear System (Display Model)" or thing:793603.

title: Dual extruder mount with auto bed leveling and 2 fans for Prusa i3 Sunhokey

description.text:
Dual bowden extruder for Prusa i3 Sunhokey with auto bed leveling. I just designed this project and I'm testing and calibrating dual color printing. I referred to these designs: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763804 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:742947 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:817538. Added new X carriage which can fit linear bearings SCS8LUU upgrade: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:813458.
NOTE: If your Sunhokey 3D printer came with MKS Gen 2Z V 1.1 board you cannot add the second extruder but you need to upgrade your PBC board to MKS Gen V 1.1 and make some changes to the file Configuration.h and Pins.h on Marlin firmware. Just uploaded Configuration.h and Pins.h files configured MKS Gen v 1.3 with dual extruder and Full Graphics Smart LCD.
I sliced with Cura engine and printed dual support.stl and fan_mount.stl with support material (Lines) and 30% infill.

description.text:
For those who own the Hurricane Canless Air system, the default detachable spout that comes with the kit is a simple straw(s) that is prone to being accidentally cracked. These spouts are more permanent solutions.   
A) The first design reduces the size of the spout so that the jet is better directed, but is also less powerful - probably more suitable for sensitive dusting.   
B) The second design is a direct replacement of the original spout - no reduction in volume of air.  
C) This one creates a linear volume of air which may be more useful for sweeping or cleaning motions. The volume of air has been calculated to be the same (the cross sectional area of the linear dimension is the same as the circular output).
Depending on your 3D printer, you may need to scale the spouts up or down to size them correctly for your printer. The current design works for 1.75mm filament printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal.

description.text:

title: Birdcage with swing  (3D printable parts+some assembly needed)

description.text: Birdcage with a swing. I have included Three Bird Models ZIP file by pmoews.

You should print top and bottom parts, as well as a swing seat. Then use standard 3mm (PLA or ABS) strings of same length (8 pieces)  and connect top and bottom parts (I have used soldering iron successfully for this). Attach swing using a string of any kind. Place a bird on swing... ;-) This model has some problems, and I will try to make a next version with a better swing, and maybe with a door as well.  
Feel free to contact me and ask for any help in printing and assembling!  
Z.

Here are 5 examples of the regular faced toroidal polyhedra of Bonnie Stewart from his book "Adventures Among the Toroids."  The outer structure is a rhombitruncated cubeoctahedron.  The internal cavity is a rhombicuboctahedron.  Various numbers of square cupolas are removed to connect the two and create toroidal polyhedra.  There are other variations of this that I hope to post in the near future.

Simple paste extruder made of MDF with a CNC.  
Done some initial tests extruding sugar icing and this looks promising! There will be a lot of trial and error and calibration of the different nozzles.   
I also think that some of the movable parts of the extruder must be replaced by a tougher material than MDF as it is quite tough load as the motor presses the material out of the syringe. Considering either to 3d print this part or make it in plywood (or maybe aluminium).

Attached are all the SVG files needed to create the CNC-parts of the machine. Note that in the picture the mount holes for the Nema17 are missing - forgot to define drilling in makercam! The pieace "extrude_movable_ends" must be milled twice. The files are created for 10mm MDF plates and are designed to be milled with 3mm diameter bit. In addition you need
4 x 230mm 8mm rods
1 608 bearing
4 x LM8UU 8mm Linear Bushing for the movable part/slider
1 8mm threaded rod
1 M8 bolt for the sliding axis
1 NEMA 17
Some M6 nuts and bolts
Some M5 nuts and bolts to join the three movable parts (there are 4 screwholes for this). .

description.text: 3D Print your own Arduino Uno Shield

I made a 3D model of the Arduino Uno board used this to create a custom shield for a project.  I put most of the holes in the model, but found it was quite easy to add any additional holes with a small drill bit.  
The header pins are super glued in place to make the basic shield.  The shield wiring is 30 GA wire wrap wire.  The wire is wrapped once around the pin using a tiny flat head screwdriver tip, then soldered the wire to the pin.

I bought a pegboard a while back and thought it would be handy to have a place to begin when designing things to hold my tools or whatever else I want to put on my pegboard. My pegboard has holes that are about 7mm wide. The center of each hole is about 25mm from the center of the next hole.  
Right now I just have 2 pegs through 5 pegs, but I've also added a template that makes adding even more pegs easy enough. Just click a vertices in one of the pegs, move it 25mm to the right or the left, and adjust the body. Then you just have to connect everything and walla, more pegs. I'm going to try experimenting with vertical pegs too sooner or later, but I have no idea if that will work. We'll find out.  
These pegs are really sturdy when printed right, but when I first found the design, one of the pegs would always snap off because it wasn't properly connected. To ensure the pegs are properly connected, look at the peg from inside of the box and ensure you can see into it. I'll attach a picture so you can see what I'm talking about.  
I originally took this design from something else, but I can't seem to find it. I've basically recreated it several times over while trying to get it to work right, but I'd still like to give the original author credit, so please let me know if you know where I found it.  
EDIT: I finally got around to trying out a second row. It fits my pegboard exactly and holds it very firm. I've uploaded the .stl and .blend files above

title: Clamp for on plank with rod underneath

description.text: Yet more plank clamp things, what can i say, i have a plank above my table. This one basically only cares about plank thickness and minimum distance from the wall. (20.2mm and 6mm resp.) You have to provide a sufficiently long rod to stick underneath. (as usual you can use tape/file a bit) The rod isnt in there you have to make/find own of the correct length; longer than pl-2*dx = pl - 23mm. The 'safety pin' isnt included either.(Its from another print i heated a nail through) It comes in a few variants, converted a small and big one to stl and also a big one in two parts.(If the print area isnt big enough.) I put stuff on my o-jasper/various-physibles github as usual. Of course the parameters said here can be changed. Note: initially i used pfte tube on the rod to make it rotate. However this was a bad idea, as it is 'sticky'; the large static friction vs dynamic friction makes it move 'earthquake style'. Basically once it starts rotating it rotates a bunch, releasing a bunch of filament. It is much better to have it rotate slowly, it has much less potential for the filament to get stuff. The filament drive can easily pull against the friction of the spool holder.(But not against tangles)

title: Printer Hook for Wallace M8 and Feet.

description.text:
While using my Wallace 8mm version, I noticed the motors occilating up and down.  
So, I designed a pair of Feet to support the outer edges.  
After I'd done that I realised I now had a place to attach my favorite Spool hook!  
So Here it is!  
Note: While this hook can support all the spools of my previous designs. It will lean over when holding a 2kg roll. 1.5kg or less, no problems.

For just the Motor Feet, if you already have a spooling option you like. :) Print: 2 x Motor_Foot
2 x MSpacer Slide Foot over end of motor. use 2 M3 10mm screws and washers on 1 MSpacer and secure motor to Foot. For Intigrated Hook option: Print:
1 x Motor_Foot
1 x Hook_Foot
1 x Hook_Top
2 x MSpacers Attach Hook Top to Hook Foot. Assemble as above.
The Hook has to go on the X-idler end. Enjoy.

author: Komb

description.text: Model of the house is based on the construction drawings. These drawings are converted from PPT to SVG and imported in Tinkercad. By exploding these drawing lines, a complete 3D Exploded View of the house is created. After exporting from Tinkercad, the STL file is imported in Cura and printed on a Arduino Materia 101 3D printer with 1.75mm silver PLA. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bydBv0WeKn9

1) Open in Tinkercad
2) Export to STL
3) Import STL in CURA
4) Export to G-CODE
5) Print on 3D Printer

title: Wall mount for iPhone 6 with Apple Leater Cover + Screw Holes to access to Head Phone and Power Plug

description.text: I wanted to create a easy mountable iPhone 6 holder which I would be able to use in combination with the original Apple Leather iPhone Cover. Screw holes make it simple to mount it to a wall. To make it easy in use, I create space to use the power plug and head phone connector, without the need to remove the phone from the iPhone holder. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5GsLo4v1WOu
